body:
Will the RH7 build be enabled on daily basis to ensure that new code change doesn't introduce build and run-time regressions with RH7?

I had made an attempt to build on RH7 earlier via #1260  , but the new code caused build failures again. So, it is good idea to introduce daily builds on RH7

Thanks @mashengchen. Now I get it. You have refactored to call another constructor within a constructor.  I remember there was one constructor of T4Statement (that is called internally) where the weakReference shouldn't be constructed. I am hoping that remains the same way even now.

Yes, Selva, I created a JIRA to track the new code change, there is another PR to fix all current issues. But to enable new jenkins for RH7, I assume we need a working build first.
I plan to discuss this on mail list after these two changes merged.
Then before the jenkins setup, I plan to monitor the changes and tried on RH7 until Jenkins setup.
@sbroeder Hi, Sean, could you help to take a review of this change?
@SuJinpei do you still work on this PR?
@Weixin-Xu This PR needs to solve the conflicting
I found the test failed caused by license issue of the vs2015 project file. But original vs2013 project file didn't contain license declaration too. Could anyone help me?
Note: I will be running full regressions overnight tonight on a workstation for this change. Please do not merge this until I report back on that.

This feature requires a change in the compiler/optimizer to ensure the reading from hdfs file is not split when the file is compressed.  @sureshsubbiah Can you please make changes in the compiler/optimizer area and add some regression tests for compressed files in your spare time?

In future we would need to consider support for splitable compression files.

@selvaganesang i think what you descript is TrafT4Statement(); i did not change the behavior that.
also i check all constructor, and there is no add behavior and no lose behavior.
FYI: Full regressions on a workstation passed for this change overnight last night. So this is OK to merge.

+1
Looks good. Sorry, I feel bad about suggesting a change that touches so many places...
@selvaganesang, does this look good to you now? Should we merge it?
Thanks @zellerh for the review. I made this change because it could have caused more problems even with just 64MB of byteArraySize.

Thanks Selva, @DaveBirdsall do you still have concerns? I later need to check each gcc versions, the latest is GCC 8.1
That will take a lot of time. So I suggest we first support gcc 4.8, which CentOS/RH 7 , that latest CentOS7.5 is still using gcc 4.8.5, not newer GCC, so I think this change will serve Trafodion for a long time.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2645/
I will run full regression and fix all issues. But it will be very appreciated one can review the basic ideas. Thanks in advance!

PushLocalFrame is called in JavaObjectInterfaceTM::initJNIEnv.  The PopLocalFrame needs to be called after initJNIEnv is called succcessfully. It looks like PopLocalFrame wasn't called earlier. This can cause memory leaks in the process.  The leak observed in mxosrvr outside of SQL accounted memory could be due to this too.

I don't believe this is the correct fix. I notice that if I do a "showplan select * from t3015 where a1=27380468" (without quotes around the number), the expression generated does not involve floats at all, rather it sticks to BIGNUM data types. I suspect that is what we should do in the '27380468' quoted string case as well: We should convert the string literal to a BIGNUM type then do BIGNUM comparison. @anoopsharma00, what do you think?
@selvaganesang and @zellerh, does this change look ready to merge now?
All the comments I had are answered, so don't have any objections.

You are right Dave, I didn't realize there is a BIGNUM data type. Let me check it. And very appreciated to hear from Anoop's advice.
Decimal will use string as storage, I was always thinking NUMERIC will use 8 bytes to store the value. So precision 19 is out of scope of 64bit. We may already save NUMERIC (19) as BIGNUM, I need to read more into the code.

I am ok with merging this PR but the following needs to be addressed soon.
1) str.split(';') could split at the wrong place if there is ';' in string literal in the given sql string.  This could result in unintended syntax error.
2) Transaction semantics needs to be clarified. 

I had raised these concerns earlier too

I'm concerned that the issue Selva points out (incorrect parsing of semicolons) is not just a potential syntax error, but a potential security vulnerability -- via SQL injection into string values.  If so, then "fix it later" is not good enough. It needs to be fixed before this is merged.
Thanks @svarnau for pointing that out. I didn't sufficiently pick that up out of @selvaganesang's comments. I agree: the parsing issue needs to be fixed to avoid SQL injection vulnerabilities.
Thanks, very good point! That always makes me think of this cartoon: https://xkcd.com/327/.
jenkins, retest -- updated RH7 build machine image
This is a wrong fix. Close it.

@svarnau can you give an example for SQL injection. actually, after split(";"), each query will invode statement or preparedstatement by user define, if use statement there will meet SQL injection, but there certainly will meet, to avoid this ,we should use preparedStatement.
actually user can only know he/she use preparedStatement by using conn.prepareStatement(sql); in our code it will create multi prepareStatement for each query, so i can't image how to meet a sql inject

@svarnau 
after open allowMultiQueries, coder can use conn.preparedStatement("select * from A where a=?;select * from B where b=?"); to do prepare in one statement.
For each query there acutally create a separated pstmt, that means there will still use preparedStatement, so if user do sql inject, and set 'A;drop table A' , our sql engine will find out this inject i think , and throw exception.
for conn.createStatement("select * from A where a=" +"A;drop table A" );.  I think even close allowMultiQueries there will have problem
Thanks @svarnau for bringing this up.. Yes, I agree it is a potential security vulnerabilty
@mashengchen - Not sure I can craft a convincing exploit, just saying the potential is there. The statements need to be parsed more carefully to be on the safe side.

Sorry for the late response. Earlier, I reviewed the change without considering the overall impact of this feature.  On further thinking, I have the following question.

If we can't modify the storage policy at hbase table level and choose to do it at hdfs level, how do you plan to take care of new data files created via data ingestion and the compaction at Hbase level.

hi @selvaganesang , the storage policy is now set at the top level data dir for a given table, so new data files should be inherit it
For compaction, the final data file is still under that data dir, so it is same. But the intermediate files generated I need to check, but I feel it is allowed.
@traflm Can you also check what happens if there is a region split?

Try this query  select * from "A\\"; drop table A;"
or
select * from a "A\\"; drop table a ;"
